This report was prepared by W. Lincklaen Arriens, Lead Water Resources Specialist, 
RSAN (Chair, Water Sector Committee) with input from the members of the Water Sector 
Committee.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  On 16 January 2001, the Board of Directors approved the Asian Development Bank's 
(ADB) policy on water1 following extensive consultations with stakeholders over several years. 
In addition to promoting national water sector reforms, integrated water resources management, 
and better water services for the poor, the policy commits ADB to regional and subregional 
cooperation by assisting with water sector assessments and exchange of data, enhancing 
awareness and understanding of the water sector issues and needs of each country, and 
supporting water partnerships in its developing member countries (DMCs).  
 
2.  On 10 December 2001, the Board approved the establishment of the Cooperation Fund 
for the Water Sector (the Fund).  The Fund is a multi-agency umbrella facility to promote 
effective water management policies and practices at the regional, subregional, and country 
levels and thereby to catalyze the implementation of ADB’s water policy in the Asia and Pacific 
region.  The Fund will finance a coherent program of activities (the Program) designed to add 
value to the water projects carried out by ADB’s regional departments. The activities will 
increase synergy in ADB’s water sector operations as a whole through better awareness, 
knowledge  management,  capacity  building  to  support  generic  sector  reforms,  pilot 
demonstration, regional cooperation, monitoring, and coordination.   
 
3.  In December 2001, the Government of the Netherlands made an initial contribution of 
$4 million to the Fund for the Program’s activities in 2002, for which technical assistance 
(TA) 6031-REG  was  approved  by  ADB’s  Board.2  The initial contribution of $4 million has 
already been committed, and the approved  activities under TA 6031 cover all six approved 
categories of the Program, including (i) promotion and public awareness; (ii) knowledge base 
and capacity building; (iii) pilot demonstrations; (iv) water partnerships; (v) regional events and 
initiatives; and (vi) program coordination, monitoring, and evaluation.  
 
4.  The  Government  of  the  Netherlands  made  a  second  contribution  to  the  Fund  in 
December 2002 in the amount of $4 million. ADB's Water Sector Committee has recommended 
that two regional TAs be processed to utilize this second contribution for the Program’s activities 
in 2003. The first regional TA will support the organization of the 3rd World Water Forum (WWF), 
to be held in Kyoto, Japan, on 16-23 March 2003. The TA framework is in Appendix 1.3 
A second TA will be prepared to support other activities of the Program. 
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
5.  The Board paper establishing the Fund identified three areas of priority assistance in the 
implementation of ADB’s water policy and the national water policies in the Asia and Pacific 
region.  The first area is assistance to DMCs for water sector assessments and national water 
action  agendas,  designing  and  implementing  critical  water  sector  reforms;  and  for 
demonstrating these reforms through pilot initiatives at the appropriate levels, involving national 
water partnerships and river basin organizations to ensure broad stakeholder participation.  The 
second concerns revising ADB’s business processes and strengthening its internal capacity to 
target  the  water  sector  more  holistically  in  its  operations,  with  greater  synergy  through 
knowledge  management  and  collaboration  with  development  partners.    The  third  is  to

strengthen regional cooperation and awareness of important water issues, trends, and policies, 
and to catalyze a new generation of water sector investments that follow from effective water 
management policies and sector reforms.  The formulation of the Program is driven by priority 
assistance needs identified on an annual basis in these three areas, and indicators are being 
developed to monitor progress in each area.  
 
6.  In strengthening regional cooperation among DMCs and ADB in the water sector, the 
Program  takes  advantage  of  the  ongoing  preparations  for  the  WWF.  The  WWF  is  being 
convened to raise awareness of the critical water issues of the looming water crisis in the 
21st century, and to mobilize actions and resources to address these issues. The 3rd WWF will 
focus on specific actions being taken around the world to implement the vision and framework 
for action prepared at the 2nd WWF in March 2000 in The Hague, the Netherlands, with specific 
and  increased  attention  to  water  and  poverty  as  a  key  element  to  attain  the  millennium 
development goals.  
 
7.  ADB’s water sector operations are highly relevant to the themes of the WWF, and ADB 
has already taken a leading role in organizing several thematic sessions in close collaboration 
with its development partners, supported by TA 6001-REG.4 These themes include (i) water and 
poverty, (ii) water in cities, (iii) water in small island countries, (iv)  regional cooperation for 
shared water resources management, and (v) flood management. Preparatory activities in 2002 
have included regional consultations with DMC stakeholders and development partners for each 
of these themes. A Water Awareness Program was also developed to support the preparations 
in  each  of  the  thematic  areas  through  media  relations,  promotional  materials,  television 
documentaries,  and  an  exhibit  at  the  World  Summit  on  Sustainable  Development  in 
Johannesburg.  
 
8.  ADB has also undertaken to organize the Water Development Partners Panel at the 
WWF to facilitate dialogue among leaders of development financing institutions, including ADB, 
and WWF stakeholders on the subject of water and poverty reduction. ADB has also joined the 
World Panel on Water Infrastructure Financing, which will make its recommendations at the 
WWF. A ministerial conference will be held at the conclusion of the WWF on 22-23 March 2003, 
at which ADB has been invited to participate, as well as in a meeting of agriculture ministers to 
be held on 21 March 2003. In preparation for the ministerial conference, ADB staff participated 
in preparatory meetings during 2002.  
 
9.  From an operational perspective, it is desirable that the 3rd WWF facilitate specific water 
sector reforms, actions, and programs undertaken by DMCs, international organizations, and 
nongovernment  organizations  that  can  be  further  promoted  through  ADB’s  water  sector 
operations. In this connection, several initiatives have already been identified and prepared for 
the WWF in the thematic areas indicated in para. 7 as a result of the regional consultation 
workshops held in 2002.   
 
10.  The WWF is expected to attract more than 8,000 participants from around the world, and 
about 150 ministers for the ministerial conference. ADB’s preparatory activities for the WWF 
have been undertaken in close collaboration with agencies concerned in Japan, including the 
Secretariat of the WWF and the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, and Transport (MLIT), which 
will  host  the  ministerial  conference.  Following  the  successful  completion  of  the  regional 
consultation workshops in 2002, ADB has been requested by the WWF Secretariat to finance a 
significant number of participants from developing countries to attend the WWF in Kyoto,

especially for the sessions organized with ADB support. The Government of the Netherlands 
has been consulted on the use of the Fund for this purpose and has no objection to support 
participants in connection with ADB-organized sessions at WWF.  
 
11.  Additional  TA  resources  are  therefore  required  from  the  Fund  to  support  the 
ADB-organized  sessions  at  the  WWF,  including  the  participation  of  presenters,  DMC 
stakeholders, development partners, and resource persons (including ADB staff concerned); the 
organization of exhibits and publicity; and the initiation of follow-up activities to ensure that the 
main lessons learned from the WWF can be applied in ADB-financed water sector operations in 
the region.   
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output  
12.  The  TA  will  support  the  ADB-organized sessions at the WWF and the initiation of 
follow-up activities to implement WWF lessons in ADB-financed water sector operations in the 
region.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  The TA comprises the following activities: 
 
14.  Travel Support for Selected DMC Participants.  About 150 participants from DMCs 
are expected to share their experiences in the various sessions on (i) water and poverty, 
(ii) water in cities, (iii) water in small island countries, (iv) regional cooperation for shared water 
resources management, and (v) flood management, as well as in the Water Development 
Partners Panel session. The participants to be supported will be selected based on their 
involvement in these themes, in which ADB has taken a leading role.    
 
15.  Travel Support for Staff Invited as Speakers and Resource Persons.  A number of 
ADB staff have been invited as speakers and resource persons in the various sessions and 
dialogues at the WWF. In addition to the ADB-organized sessions, these include (i) water and 
governance, led by the Global Water Partnership; (ii) integrated water resources management; 
(iii) flood management, in collaboration with the Japanese International Cooperation Agency, 
MLIT, and the World Meteorological Organization; (iv) the dialogue for water and climate, led by 
the Government of the Netherlands; and (v) the dialogue on water for food and environment, led 
by the International Water Management Institute. 
  
16.  Exhibits and Publications. ADB’s Water Awareness Program, which was launched in 
2002 under TA-6031, has produced publicity materials, videos, a web page, and publications to 
disseminate ADB’s water policy and key development messages in the water sector, and to 
increase public awareness and stakeholder dialogue  on water  reform issues, including the 
themes organized by ADB for the 3rd WWF. Printing and distribution for the WWF will be 
arranged, an exhibit will be organized at the WWF, and journalists from DMCs will be invited to 
cover the ADB-organized and related sessions at the WWF.

4       
17.  Initiation  of  Follow-Up  Activities.  Follow-up  activities  will  be  initiated,  with  the 
assistance of consultants, to  ensure that the main lessons learned from the WWF can be 
applied in ADB-financed water sector operations in the region.5  
 
18.  Administrative, Logistics, and Other Supporting Activities. These activities include 
administrative, shipping, local support, reporting, and miscellaneous costs in connection with the 
WWF. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing  
19.  The total cost of the TA, estimated at $1.00 million, will be financed on a grant basis 
from the Cooperation Fund  for  the  Water  Sector, to  be  administered  by  ADB.  The cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  The TA will be implemented by ADB.  The Agriculture, Natural Resources, and Social 
Sectors  Division  (RSAN)  of  the  Regional  and  Sustainable  Development  Department,  in 
association with concerned divisions in the regional departments, will be responsible for all TA 
activities. The Water Sector Committee will serve as the TA team.  The lead water resources 
specialist of RSAN will coordinate the team’s activities.  
 
21.  The water focal point in RSAN will serve as TA office. Approximately 9 person-months of 
international  and  12  person-months  of  domestic  consultants  will  be  needed  for  the 
implementation of the activities of the TA by RSAN. The areas of expertise that may be required 
for WWF follow-up activities include water policy and institutional development, water sector 
capacity building, knowledge management and information systems, rural water supply and 
sanitation, integrated water resources management, flood management, water supply and utility 
management, natural resources economics, social research and development, and related 
disciplines. It is expected that approximately three international consultants will be required, one 
each  for  the  five  areas  mentioned  in  para.  15,  supported  by  approximately  five  domestic 
consultants in the DMCs that express interest in follow-up activities as a result of the WWF. The 
consultants will be recruited as individuals.6 ADB will recruit the consultants in accordance with 
its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the 
recruitment of consultants.  Outline terms of reference are shown in Appendix 3.  Equipment 
and  materials  to  be  financed  by  the  TA  will  be  procured  by  the  consultants  or  ADB  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement or other procedures acceptable to ADB.7  
 
22.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 6 months, commencing in February 2003 
and ending in August 2003.  A final report will be prepared in August 2003. The report will be 
published in the ADB website.  
 
                                                 
5  Areas in which follow-up activities are expected include (i) the proposed Water for Asian Cities Program, for which 
the President and the Executive Director of United Nations Habitat signed a letter of intent at the World Summit on 
Sustainable Development in Johannesburg; (ii) the proposed Rural Water and Poverty Action Program, which was 
conceived  at  the  Regional  Consultation  Workshop  on  Water  and  Poverty  in  Dhaka  in  September  2002; 
(iii) subregional flood management initiatives of the Mekong River Commission; and other activities as needed and 
deemed appropriate. 
6  The required expertise is diverse, with inputs required in different themes that are led by ADB staff in several 
departments and offices. 
7  Equipment may include computers, software, multimedia instruments, and equipment for demonstration projects.

5
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 to be financed on 
a grant basis by the Cooperation Fund for the Water Sector for Promoting Effective Water 
Management Policies and Practices – Phase 2, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

8      Appendix 3         
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
1.  International and domestic short-term water sector specialists will be engaged to work in 
the Agriculture, Natural Resources, and Social Services Division and regional departments 
concerned to  undertake the following tasks, in close collaboration with and guided by the 
Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) Water Sector Committee. 
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
2.  The international consultants will 
   
(i)  support  the  ADB-organized sessions at the 3rd World Water Forum (WWF), 
including  thematic  and  panel  sessions,  ministerial  meetings,  and  associated 
media events; 
 
(ii)  consult with developing member country (DMC) stakeholders and development 
partners  to  mobilize  commitment  for  follow-up  activities  after  the  WWF,  in 
particular for the proposed (a) Water for  Asian Cities Program, for which the 
President and the Executive Director of United Nations Habitat signed a letter of 
intent at the World Summit on Sustainable Development in Johannesburg in 
2002; (b) Rural Water and Poverty Action Program, which was conceived at the 
Regional  Consultation  Workshop  on  Water  and  Poverty  in  Dhaka  in 
September 2002; (c) subregional flood management initiatives of the Mekong 
River Commission; and (d) other follow-up activities to be agreed upon as a 
result of the WWF; 
 
(iii)  prepare letters of intent and memoranda of understanding among ADB, DMC 
agencies, and development partners for such follow-up activities; 
 
(iv)  for  agreed  upon  follow-up  activities,  prepare  detailed  proposals  including 
objectives,  project  framework,  scope,  cost  estimates  and  financing  plan, 
implementation plan and arrangements, and terms of reference for consulting 
services, and advise ADB about the initiation of the activities as needed; and 
 
(v)  prepare a final report on ADB’s support to the WWF and the follow-up activities 
agreed upon, outlining the preparatory activities and summarizing the sessions.  
 
B.  Domestic Consultants 
 
3.  The domestic consultants will assist the international consultants in DMCs that express 
an interest in follow-up activities as a result of the WWF, through data collection, consultations, 
and proposal development with agencies and development partners in the DMCs concerned.
